div.p: I.e. subject of study. This content sub-element in BIOGRAPHY EDUCATION , generally encloses a word or phrase, and records areas of study which are significant to a writer's education. It has one attribute, REG, to explain non-standard terms (<SUBJECT REG="HISTORY‚Äù>kings and queens of England</>). We are particularly interested in subjects which influenced her writing (for example, she studied archeology and her first novel was set at an archeological dig), classical language studies for women writers in the early period (recording the importance of ancient languages as a masculine domain, and the acquisition of translation skills), and other subjects which were non-traditional for women (for example, engineering). Tag reading and writing as subjects only during periods when they were remarkable. Be selective about subjects, depending on breadth of curriculum and how much information is available. Fill in the keyref attributes once glossentry topics for the specified elements exist (use the id attribute on the glossentry element.

div.codeblock: VA's father, horrified at her relationship with a young woman, sent her to a Domestic Training College at Eastbourne, to learn <SUBJECT>Domestic Economy</SUBJECT>. Her mother ensured that SA was given a thorough education that included <SUBJECT>Latin</SUBJECT>, <SUBJECT>mathematics</SUBJECT>, <SUBJECT>philosophy</SUBJECT>, and <SUBJECT>political economy</SUBJECT>

div.p: Only subjects which had a significant impact or were central to the person should be tagged. If her major in university was geography, or if she took a course in it which interested her particularly, then tag it; if she studied geography as part of a wide-ranging syllabus in secondary school, probably not. Use a separate subject tag for each subject specified. Do not put one tag around a phrase like she studied history, philosophy, and literature.
